title: 109_hr4946
content: The "Berry Amendment Extension Act" imposes a Buy-American requirement on the Department of Homeland Security with exceptions. The "Berry Amendment Extension Act" imposes a Buy-American requirement on the Department of Homeland Security for certain items related to national security interests. This prohibits the use of funds for items not grown, reprocessed, reused, or produced in the United States. Covered items include clothing, tents, tarpaulins, cotton, and other natural fiber products. The "Berry Amendment Extension Act" requires the Department of Homeland Security to buy American-made clothing, tents, tarpaulins, cotton, silk, synthetic fabric, wool, specialty metals, hand tools, and measuring tools for national security purposes. The Act prohibits the use of funds for items not produced in the United States, with exceptions determined by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Berry Amendment Extension Act mandates the purchase of American-made products for national security, with exceptions for certain procurements outside the US and small purchases below a specified threshold. The section applies to contracts and subcontracts for commercial items, including exceptions for certain procurements and notification requirements within 7 days of contract award. The term "United States" includes US possessions. During Fiscal Year 2006, the Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure that acquisition workforce members receive training on textile acquisition requirements. Any new training programs must include this information. Additionally, consistency with international agreements is required. Additionally, the Secretary, in consultation with the United States Trade Representative, shall determine the inapplicability of any provision of the Act that conflicts with international agreements. Effective Date: This section applies to contracts entered into by the Department of Homeland Security after the enactment of this Act.
